Welcome to episode 3 of our
Conflict Management series.

In the previous two episodes, I went through
4 tips on how to manage conflict effectively
in the workplace.

Today we’re going to go through 
the last two tips.

Here is tip number five on how to
manage conflict well.
Own it

Or said a little bit differently - Take responsibility
for your part in the problem.

You’re not coming up with any ideas
for the gala!

How can we make it a night to remember if
you don’t get the creative juices flowing?

Yeh, I’m sorry, I’m having a bit of a
mind blank.
Have you come up with anything?

Even if you’re convinced that your colleague
is mainly at fault, there’s always a part

that you’ve had to play in creating that
conflict or that problem.

Maybe you were a bit too harsh
in your response.

Maybe you didn’t give your colleague enough
time to get the work done, or maybe you just

used one exclamation mark too many
in your email.

The point is, recognising that you’ve had
a part to play in the current conflict, being

accountable and taking responsibility will
create a space where, whoever you’re in

conflict with will also self-examine and take
ownership for whatever it is that they need
to take ownership for.

Conflict management isn’t an opportunity
for you to find ways of blaming your colleagues,

but it’s an opportunity to find a way to
work together as a team.
Number 6: Focus on the future

Recently I’ve started to notice how much
time we spend on looking at what should’ve
or could’ve been done differently.

And I’ve also started to notice that usually
when these comments are made, they’re
particularly unhelpful.

Hello and welcome everybody to this very important
conference that we have been planning for
over one year.
You should’ve put more money in the comms budget.

Now don’t get me wrong, it is helpful to
talk about what should’ve and what could’ve
been done differently within a specific context.
For example, in a debrief.

The casually said, “you should’ve done
this” or “you could’ve done this”
isn’t the same thing.

That kind of comment can sound more like an
accusation rather than a constructive critique.
Are you still with me?
Here’s a very practical piece of advice.

Next time you feel the urge to talk about
what should’ve or could’ve been done,

set up a meeting with your colleague 
and call it a debrief.

You can then spend 25% of that time looking
at what should’ve or could’ve been done

better, and the rest of the meeting looking
at how you can implement these solutions
in the future.

And that my friends brings us to the end of
the conflict management series.
Can you think of any tips that we’ve missed?

Or anything that maybe helped you when you
were in a conflictual situation?

Write them in the comments because we all
need to improve in this particular skill.

More Business English videos will be coming
your way very soon so make sure you subscribe,

and if you’re looking for expert help specifically
for English in the workplace,
check out English Online, the link is in the description.

You should be able to see episodes 1 and 2
to my left here so if you haven’t watched them,
make sure you go and watch them now.
See you in our next series!
Bye!
